comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Druids Alter, Islandmagee This is "Ballylumford Dolmen" or locally known as the Druids Altar. The Druids Altar could be 4000 years old, or it could be an even earlier passage grave. It consists of 4 upright stones, with a heavy capstone, and a fallenstone within the structure .This could have been put there to block the entrance to the tomb. islandmagee.webs.com/photos.htm

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The 1913 phone book at Lennon-Wylie lists the Belfast Mineral Water Co. Ltd., Aerated Water Manufacturers on York Road. The 1884 map shows nada, as does the 1895. In the 1901-1903 map, the Belfast Mineral Water works appears, along with Mineral Street (which is still there!).

comment._content: The house is a really unusual design for that period - looks almost art deco in style.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Whereas some megalithic monuments are difficult to find, this neat 'Druid's Altar' could hardly be more conspicuous or accessible: it even has an address, 91 Ballylumford Road, Islandmagee, the result of an unlikely juxtaposition of a house of the living alongside a house of the dead. Ballylumford dolmen (second image) When The Dublin Penny Journal published the accompanying woodcut in 1833, the tomb stood out as a solitary landmark at the relatively remote northern end of this peninsula. The present villa was built here later in the century and this 4000-year-old megalith became thoroughly domesticated, and is now a unique garden eye-catcher trimmed with flowers round the base..... An early account states that it was formerly surrounded by a circle of standing stones, probably the revetment of a cairn, any trace of which has disappeared. A gold collar reportedly found here long ago is unlikely to have had any connection with the dolmen.. www.irelandseye.com/aarticles/travel/nature/landscape/anc...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] definitely not Art Deco then!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Here they say the house is Edwardian? and also show what looks like part of the house in an ink sketch entitled Nineteenth-century ink sketch of Ballylumford Dolmen (JRSAI 16,1883-4). Who Knows? Ballylumford Dolmen (NISMR Ref: Ant 041:004) Situated in front of an Edwardian house on the summit of a steep sided N/S ridge. The megalith consists of three angular basalt orthostats on which is set a substantial capstone which tilts down to the distal end. Within the chamber is a recumbent slab. www.bnfc.org.uk/New_Site_BNFC/Islandmagee.html

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Re-eyeballing the map, OS-10-1-41-5-1 is the 1902-03, and OS-10-1-41-5-2 is the 1921. They do look different, but at the highest zoom, the change seems to be that an adjoining older building (called Druid's Cottage in 1857) has been knocked down. In the archive is a shot with the adjoining building looking rather old. Also is a shot with the adjoining building looking renovated (and this house with a different paint job), and here the different paintjob and a different dog.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, I'll have to withdraw my map-based post-1903 date, and fall back on the Belfast Mineral from York Road as being after 1895.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The DIA suggests the Belfast Mineral Water Company dates from 1886: Date: 1886 Nature: Office, stores, stables & yard. 'at present being erected'. Doesn't specify York Road though. It later refers to a factory and stores at York Road, but not until 1907.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: William John Arthurs was born in Carnspindle on May 4, 1853, and was baptized on May 14, 1853. He died on Oct.22, 1896, and is remembered in the above gravestone inscription. He may be the son who was known as Capt. Arthurs and who was associated with the Druids Altar, an ancient monument near Ballylumford. www.dankat.com/earls/chap6.htm

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Well, well, well, Niall! Turn my back for a moment and you're backtracking on dates, luring people off to the opposition (only joking, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/proni/], honest!) and dangling online directories in front of people while I was up in our Stacks sweating over hard copy Belfast and Province of Ulster Directories. The online ones, while excellent, only go up to 1900 (trying to be mature, and not go Nah nah nah nah nah). I found out some dating stuff about Thomas McFerran, Druid's Altar and the next incumbent of the house between 1900 and 1914. Will put it together in some sort of logical format now...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
All from Belfast and Province of Ulster Directory: 1901 Thomas M'Ferran, grain merchant is living in Islandmagee, but at Ballycronnanmore 1902 It's only in this year that Islandmagee gets a much better introductory description before the listings for officialdom and other inhabitants start. Tourism is on the rise. 2 ferries; better railways; and a "fine new road" has been opened. This is the first year that the dolmen gets a mention:
The Druid's Altar, at the residence of Mr. Thomas M'Ferran, Ballylumford, is well worth a visit...
And in the list of inhabitants, M'Ferran is listed as living at Druid's Altar. 1909 Thomas M'Ferran disappears from the list of inhabitants, although the initial description of Islandmagee still says: "The Druid's Altar, at the residence of Mr. Thomas M'Ferran, Ballylumford, is well worth a visit..." 1910 Now the Druid's Altar is spoken of as being "at the residence of Mr. Saml. Crawford, Ballylumford" in the introduction to Islandmagee, and Samuel Crawford is listed under inhabitants as living at Druid's Altar. 1914 Druid's Altar still mentioned as worth a visit in introductory paragraph, but not attached to anyone by name. And Samuel Crawford is down as living at Ballylumford. Wondering if our gentleman could be Thomas M'Ferran or Samuel Crawford, if taken between 1900 and 1914. Despite much earlier options because of Belfast Mineral Water crate, I think the growing tourist industry around the Antrim coastline after the turn of the century could be important, making this a must-see / must-photograph point for Robert French, especially given the fact that Islandmagee wasn't even considered worth featuring in the directories before 1900.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
From those other shots in the archive, French must have visited twice, and this shot is from the first visit. The house next door is unrenovated, there is no gate in the wall between the houses, the door is painted a dark colour and the dog is brown and white.

The other set show the house next door renovated, the doorframe painted a lighter colour, the over-window detail on the house is light on dark instead of dark on light, and the dog has been painted black.

There is at least a couple of years between the two visits, I'd say.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From Monday, 10 June 1878 in the Belfast Newsletter:
M'FERRAN June 9 at Druid's Cottage, Islandmagee, Martha, the beloved wife of Thomas M'Ferran. Her remains will be removed for interment in Ballyprior Graveyard, on to-morrow (Tuesday) at twelve o'clock noon. Friends will please accept this intimation.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
